H0.text: Mining is the human activity that primarily causes excessive algae blooms in some lakes by degrading water quality and creating conditions favorable for algae growth.

H1.text: Farming is the human activity that primarily causes excessive algae blooms in some lakes by degrading water quality and creating conditions more favorable for algae growth.

H2.text: Transportation is the human activity that primarily causes excessive algae blooms in some lakes by degrading water quality and creating conditions more favorable for algae growth.

H3.text: Manufacturing is the human activity that primarily causes excessive algae blooms in some lakes by degrading water quality and creating conditions more favorable for algae growth.

A4.text: Run-off from fertilized fields, lawns, and golf courses is a source of excessive nutrients from human activity.

A5.text: Internal combustion of fuels creates nitrogen pollution, contributing to nutrient enrichment in water bodies.

A7.text: Phosphorus is the largest contributor to eutrophication, especially in freshwaters.

A8.text: Excess phosphorus typically enters surface waters. The amount that enters surface waters is relatively low in comparison to the amount that is applied as fertilizer, but because it acts as a limiting nutrient in most environments, even a small amount can disrupt an ecosystem's natural phosphorus biogeochemical cycles.
